title: Trump Sees National Emergencies Where Experts Say There Are None
description: Mr. Trump had the authority to declare two emergencies. But they also happened to advance his favorite targets: more fossil fuels and less immigration.
content: President Trump’s return to the Oval Office came with emergency declarations for the country’s energy sector and the southern border, unleashing broad powers for situations that — in these cases — are hardly in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Ryan Mac
title: Trump Pardons Creator of Silk Road Drug Marketplace
description: Ross Ulbricht was serving a life sentence for creating a site in a shady corner of the internet to sell heroin, cocaine and other illicit substances.
content: President Trump on Tuesday granted a pardon to Ross Ulbricht, the creator of the Silk Road drug marketplace and a cult hero in the cryptocurrency and libertarian worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Trump’s opponents push back.
content: President Trump’s adversaries made their first moves yesterday, with 22 states suing to prevent him from denying citizenship rights to the children of unauthorized immigrants. It was the start of what’s likely to be a long legal battle over immigration. A union representing career federal workers also filed a lawsuit over a Trump executive order that would make it easier to fire them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Emily Cochrane
title: 2 Dead, Including Gunman, in Nashville High School Shooting, Police Say
description: A student opened fire inside Antioch High School, shooting two other students and then himself, the authorities said. A female student and the shooter were killed, officials said.
content: A 17-year-old male student armed with a pistol opened fire in a high school cafeteria in Nashville on Wednesday, fatally shooting a 16-year-old female student and injuring a 17-year-old male student before killing himself, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Raquel Minian
title: America Is a Nation of Immigrants That Has Not Lived Up to Its Promise
description: The huddled masses yearning to breathe free have not always been received with open arms.
content: Donald Trump has long explicitly challenged a foundational myth of American identity: the idea of the United States as a nation of immigrants that welcomes the world’s “huddled masses yearning to breathe free.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Remembering the House on Revello Drive
description: Claire Fahy, who attended U.C.L.A. and helped cover the fires for The Times, reflects on her own ties to the Palisades fire.
content: I kept clicking refresh, looking for the house on Revello Drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Crews Work Through the Night After Pensacola, Fla., Sees Record Snowfall
description: Unofficial, backyard tallies have recorded at least nine inches of snow. The previous record snowfall for Pensacola was three inches in 1895.
content: D.C. Reeves, the mayor of Pensacola, Fla., was out on Main and Eighth streets on Wednesday morning, talking to public works crews who plowed snow from the city’s major roads overnight. Northwest Florida saw record snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young
title: 2 Families, in Business for 50 Years, Wage War in a South Korean Boardroom
description: Control of Korea Zinc, the world’s largest producer of zinc, is at stake in a battle challenging the country’s entrenched chaebol system of powerful conglomerates.
content: When two longtime business partners established a subsidiary 50 years ago to make zinc out of an industrial complex set up by South Korea’s government, they settled on an unusual division of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Federal Workers Ordered to Report on Colleagues Over D.E.I. Crackdown
description: The warning came one day after the administration ordered that diversity, equity and inclusion efforts across the government be shut down by 5 p.m. Wednesday.
content: The Trump administration on Wednesday threatened federal employees with “adverse consequences” if they fail to report on colleagues who defy orders to purge diversity, equity and inclusion efforts from their agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Trump’s Paris Withdrawal Is Grimmer This Time
description: Eight years ago, Trump’s withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement spurred a big time reaction that shaped the decade. Now, it’s a different time.
content: The line of destructive executive action on climate was entirely predictable on President Trump’s Day 1: withdrawal from the Paris agreement, a threat to clean-energy subsidies, a promise to ban offshore wind and radically accelerate the energy permitting process (though that last one contains, potentially, some upside). It’s not yet clear how all this will net out — executive actions are memos in search of policy, and the slow decline of emissions has proved pretty stubborn lately. But it isn’t likely to be salutary, and the symbolism is undeniably grim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Solo Vacations: Traveling Alone Is Now a Group Activity
description: A growing number of tour operators are bringing individual travelers together for professionally planned trips with a new emphasis on making friends.
content: Rich Harrington had always wanted to visit Europe, but planning a trip with others felt daunting. “It’s hard enough coordinating dinner out with friends,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bee-Dazzler
description: Fasten your seatbelts, solvers, it’s going to be a bumpy ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Working With Your Hands
description: When was the last time you made something?
content: When was the last time you made something, just for the fun of it? What was the experience like?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What’s the Rule About Looking at Women in Public?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the difference between noticing women’s attractiveness and ogling them.
content: What is the rule about looking at women in public? As a red-blooded male, I would like to stare, but of course that’s rude and possibly antisocial. In the past, when I’ve taken a quick glance and got caught, I was given sharp, disapproving looks from the woman and, often, some bystanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Katy Reckdahl and Kathleen Flynn
title: Amid a Wintry Mess, New Orleans Also Savors a Spectacle
description: The storm brought both dazzling landscapes of ice and snow and challenges to a city unaccustomed to such severe winter weather.
content: The snow canceled classes and made getting to work impossible, disrupting routines and causing an array of problems in New Orleans, where most people have little or no experience navigating wintry conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Kennedy Would Keep Stake in HPV Vaccine Suit if Confirmed
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President Trump’s nominee to be health secretary, would have oversight power over the vaccine’s maker, Merck, if confirmed.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President Trump’s pick to be health secretary, is keeping his financial stake in major litigation against Merck over a widely used vaccine given to young people, according to an ethics agreement made public on Wednesday and court documents. That conflict of interest could raise questions for lawmakers as Mr. Kennedy aims to run agencies that regulate the drugmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Key Trump Nominee Hints at Push for Work Requirements in Medicaid
description: Russell T. Vought, President Trump’s nominee to run the Office of Management and Budget, said he supported work requirements for the program that supports low-income Americans.
content: Russell T. Vought, President Trump’s nominee to run the Office of Management and Budget, told Senate lawmakers in a confirmation hearing on Wednesday that he supported work requirements for low-income Americans receiving publicly subsidized health insurance, a policy that Mr. Trump pursued in his first term but that the Biden administration mostly reversed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Tries to Keep Up With Trump’s Executive Orders
description: “If you could put anything in front of him yesterday, he would have signed it,” said Ronny Chieng. “Melania, now’s your chance to update the prenup.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In Pop Culture, the End of the World Is Always Nigh
description: A new book by the British cultural journalist Dorian Lynskey chronicles our centuries-old obsession with doomsday scenarios.
content: When it comes to make-believe disasters, our appetite is endless; yet we’re loath to anticipate real-world disasters until it is too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Five deaths in Texas crash occurred after tractor-trailer struck three vehicles.
description: It started as a minor crash on a bridge between two vans, but a tractor-trailer wasn’t able to keep from hitting those gathered on the bridge.
content: The crash in Texas that killed five people on Tuesday, the deadliest incident reported so far in the Gulf Coast winter storm, occurred when a tractor-trailer lost control on an icy rural highway bridge and struck three stationary vehicles, the state police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Whipple
title: Susie Wiles Is Trump’s Best Hope
description: The incoming White House chief of staff may well represent the thin line between the president and disaster.
content: Ken Duberstein, Ronald Reagan’s final White House chief of staff, once observed that campaigning is trying to destroy your opponents, while governing is making friends with them. In his first term as president, Donald Trump did not get the difference, and his tenure was often overwhelmed by dysfunction and chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Cruises: ‘Neighborhoods,’ Private Islands and More Megaships
description: Cruise lines are creating their own beaches, reaching out to families (especially on larger ships), and creating a boutique hotel vibe for luxury clients.
content: Responding to record cruise demand, major cruise lines will continue to launch new mega-ships this year, with countless over-the-top features and amenities that will appeal to families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Trump Pardoned Her for Storming the Capitol. ‘Absolutely Not,’ She Said.
description: Pamela Hemphill, 71, of Boise, Idaho, who served 60 days in prison, said it would be “an insult to the Capitol Police” if she accepted the pardon.
content: Many of those convicted of storming the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, have celebrated the pardons or commutations that they received this week from President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Trump Expands Quick Deportations Across the U.S.
description: President Trump’s first administration tried to implement a similarly sped-up process for removing unauthorized immigrants, but those efforts were hampered by federal courts.
content: The Trump administration on Tuesday expanded the powers that Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers have to swiftly remove some undocumented immigrants from the U.S., a move that could help President Trump carry out the large-scale deportation campaign he has promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The New Rules of the Trump Era
description: Ezra Klein and Aaron Retica discuss the oligarchic power dynamics of the second Trump administration.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: At the Cloisters, Sor Juana’s Words Ring Out in Song
description: The opera “Primero Sueño” translates Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz’s poem about the soul’s journey into a musical promenade around the Cloisters.
content: The Met Cloisters were alive with the sound of music on a frigid January afternoon. Six nuns in white surrounded a seventh dressed in black, and all were singing. The scene was beautifully formal but it also felt organic, as if the women had been there for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Former Navy SEAL Said to Be Interim Head of FEMA
description: Cameron Hamilton does not appear to have experience coordinating responses to large-scale disasters, like the wildfires in California.
content: The Trump administration has made a former member of the Navy SEALs who has spoken about the importance of securing the southern border temporary administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, according to two people familiar with the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Vivian Yee, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Bishop Asks Trump to ‘Have Mercy,’ and Hegseth Faces New Accusations
description: Plus, snow on Florida’s beaches.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Harvard Adopts a Definition of Antisemitism for Discipline Cases
description: Many universities have been reluctant to embrace a definition that, among other things, considers some criticisms of Israel as antisemitic. The university’s decision was part of a lawsuit settlement.
content: Harvard University will adopt a definition of antisemitism when investigating discipline cases as part of several moves meant to protect Jewish students after Gaza war protests, the university said in an agreement on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Jones
title: This Is Who Should Foot the Bill for the Los Angeles Fires
description: It’s time to require oil and gas companies to compensate communities, homeowners, businesses and even insurers for the losses.
content: Who should pay for the costliest wildfires in American history? The disaster in Los Angeles, driven by climate change, has killed at least 27 people, destroyed more than 15,000 structures and caused up to an estimated $275 billion in damage. Insurers alone could face $30 billion in claims, increasing the likelihood that more companies will stop covering properties in California and other climate-affected states. As insurance costs soar, more homeowners may struggle to keep up with mortgage payments, risking widespread defaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Judi Dench Says She No Longer Goes to Events Alone, Citing Vision Loss
description: The veteran English actress said that she now needed to attend public events with someone else, because of her worsening macular degeneration.
content: Judi Dench, the veteran English stage and film actress, said this month that her vision loss had progressed to the point that she no longer attended red-carpet premieres and other events alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Even Religious People Don’t Trust Religious Institutions
description: And why secular people should care.
content: Daniel Reece attended church every Sunday as a child growing up in Connecticut, and he went to a Roman Catholic middle school. His parents are still deeply observant — his mother goes to Mass every day at noon, and his father is part of the church choir. Reece, who is now 37, still finds the moral values he learned through Catholicism to be profound. He feels, he explained to me, a sense of “awe of the sheer perfection that God has achieved with this planet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: It Wasn’t Just a Diner. It Was a Hub for Altadena.
description: The Little Red Hen Coffee Shop offered grits and community for decades before it was lost in the Eaton fire.
content: This is the place where an Anita Baker ballad slips through the speakers and the smell of bacon floats in an irresistible fog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $850,000 Homes in New Mexico, Virginia and Montana
description: An adobe home in Santa Fe, a Craftsman bungalow in Norfolk, and a Victorian-style house in Missoula.
content: This two-bedroom, two-bathroom house and one-bedroom, one-bathroom guesthouse were both extensively updated in 2016, with new insulation and new heating, electrical, and plumbing systems. Santa Fe Railyard, home to shops, restaurants, a farmer’s market, and a movie theater, is five minutes away by car, and Santa Fe Plaza, framed by art, history, and cultural museums, is a 10-minute drive, as is the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum. An organic grocery store and a Trader Joe’s are both within a five-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Tell Us About the One Who Got Away
description: Have you ever had a “missed connection” or a big, deep love that slipped through your fingers? We want to hear about it.
content: Maybe it was a “Before Sunrise”-esque night of romance in college, or a chance encounter with a cute stranger in the grocery store that still pops up in your dreams. Perhaps it was the high school sweetheart you didn’t fully appreciate until years later, or a great love you lost to illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Luxury Resorts: Far-Flung Settings, Fair Prices and Cooler Climes
description: Even travelers of means want their money’s worth as they go farther afield, avoiding crowds and heat waves.
content: This year, travelers of means will be checking into remote new lodges and upscale all-inclusive resorts, and demanding reasonable prices, relatively speaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: South Carolina Utility Seeks Buyers for Failed Nuclear Project
description: The utility, Santee Cooper, is trying to sell two nuclear reactors that it abandoned in 2017 as tech companies seek new sources of electricity for data centers.
content: A major power provider in South Carolina started accepting bids from buyers on Wednesday to finish two nuclear reactors, hoping to take advantage of the recent interest in the energy source from technology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Frannie Carr Toth, Sophia Lanman and Mike Peed
title: Meet the Woman Who Transformed Children’s Music
description: Long before Raffi or Dan Zanes, there was Ella Jenkins.
content: Children’s music is now recognized as a celebrated and creative genre in its own right. But that wasn’t always the case. Starting in the 1950s, Ella Jenkins, a self-taught musician, upended the industry’s moralistic norms. Jenkins eventually traveled around the world, collecting diverse musical customs and integrating them into her songs for kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: 4 Charged in Ohio Burglaries May Have Targeted Joe Burrow, Authorities Say
description: The defendants, all from Chile, are accused of participating in a South American crime group targeting multimillion-dollar homes, the authorities said. One of the targets appeared to be Mr. Burrow, the Cincinnati Bengals quarterback.
content: Four Chilean men were arrested this month in connection with a string of burglaries at multimillion-dollar homes in Ohio after a traffic stop in which the authorities found what appeared to be items taken from the residence of the Cincinnati Bengals quarterback Joe Burrow.
source.name: The New York Times
